````
title: Playing the Hacker: Inside a Prompt Hacking Challenge in Wharton Hack-AI-thon (Part II)
text:
Role-play proved to be one of the most effective techniques throughout the project.
By assigning the chatbot a new role or positioning ourselves within a role that fit naturally into the bot‚Äôs existing setting, we influenced how the model interpreted the conversation. When the interaction felt consistent with the bot‚Äôs character, responses shifted accordingly. Conversations framed as stories or scenarios encouraged the model to stay focused on maintaining coherence within that narrative.
This approach consistently worked when the assigned role aligned with the bot‚Äôs persona, the request matched the character‚Äôs worldview, and the dialogue unfolded naturally rather than as a direct instruction. Under these conditions, the model prioritized narrative consistency and character behavior, which opened paths to responses that were otherwise difficult to reach.






Emotional framing also played a noticeable role in shaping responses.
Changes in tone, urgency, or emotional intensity influenced how the chatbot evaluated the importance of a request. Messages that conveyed strong feelings, concern, or excitement often received more engaged responses. This pattern reflected how emotional language appears frequently in training data and carries strong contextual signals.
Tone functioned as part of the input, shaping how the model interpreted intent, urgency, and relevance. Subtle shifts in emotional framing sometimes led to measurable changes in compliance and openness.






Another recurring pattern involved language choice.
When prompts avoided explicit or commonly flagged terminology and relied instead on indirect or neutral phrasing, safety mechanisms triggered less frequently. The model still grasped the underlying intent through context, while keyword-based filters remained inactive. This gap highlighted the difference between semantic understanding and surface-level detection.
Careful wording allowed sensitive topics to be approached gradually, especially when combined with role-play and conversational buildup.






We also observed changes in behavior when conversations expanded beyond a single focused objective.
By introducing small talk, tangents, or unrelated questions, the chatbot‚Äôs attention spread across multiple threads. As the conversation diversified, the model‚Äôs confidence in identifying a single dominant intent decreased. This often led to more flexible responses and reduced resistance in later prompts.
This technique resembled conversational misdirection, where context accumulation altered how subsequent requests were interpreted.

 




Output format influenced how responses were generated.
Requests for tables, lists, structured summaries, or alternative formats changed the way content passed through safety checks. Some formats interacted differently with filtering mechanisms, which allowed certain information to appear when framed structurally rather than as free-form text.
This pattern suggested that safeguards were tuned unevenly across output types.



For more complex objectives, we broke requests into small, incremental steps.
Each step appeared neutral and self-contained. The model evaluated them independently and responded without referencing the broader trajectory of the conversation. Over time, these steps accumulated into outcomes that were difficult to reach in a single prompt.
This approach aligned with how models process prompts locally, focusing on immediate compliance rather than long-term conversational direction.



The patterns we observed point toward several directions for improvement. Stronger systems would benefit from deeper intent modeling beyond keyword detection, clearer prioritization among persona, policy, and business goals, output verification across multiple formats, and broader human perspectives during training and evaluation.
````

title: Introducing The First Extension I Developed: Prompt Booster
text:
What is Prompt Booster and why was it designed?
Prompt Booster was created to help users get more out of their interactions with AI. Too often, prompts are either too shallow (outsourcing all the thinking to the AI) or too generic (leading to weak or superficial responses). Prompt Booster solves this problem by automatically enhancing prompts before they‚Äôre sent with one click, giving users a smoother and quicker way to achieve richer, more reliable outputs.




Two Core Features

Prompt Boost Users can ask Prompt Booster to improve their prompts in ways that fit their goals. For example:

Transform a vague request into a comprehensive and evidence-based prompt that encourages ChatGPT to provide well-supported, verifiable responses.
Reframe a lazy or over-reliant prompt into one that guides the user to complete the task themselves, rather than asking the AI to do all the work.
Encourage deeper reflection or critical thinking by automatically rewriting prompts to push the AI toward more analytical or thought-provoking answers.

Prompt Append With a single click, users can add predefined, repeatable requirements to any new input. This saves time and ensures consistency across different tasks. For example:

Translate: Translate the above text into natural, fluent English that reads as if written by a native speaker.
Polish: Polish and refine the language to make it smoother, more professional, and stylistically consistent.
Summarize: Summarize the content clearly and concisely, highlighting the key points in a structured way.
Simplify: Rewrite this paragraph so it is easier to understand, using simpler words and clearer sentence structures.





How to Get Started with Prompt Booster

1. Install & Connect
First things first‚Äîget Prompt Booster onto your browser.

Add Prompt Booster to Chrome and pin it to your toolbar so it‚Äôs always just one click away.
Open the settings page (look for the little gear) and paste in your API key.
Not sure where to find your API key? No problem‚Äîhere‚Äôs a quick guide that walks you through it.





This is the main interface of the software. In terms of visual design, I made the buttons consistent with ChatGPT‚Äôs own buttons to achieve a clean and sophisticated style. I chose purple as the primary color‚Äînot only because it conveys a sense of elegance, but also because of my personal connection to my undergraduate alma mater, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen, where purple is one of the theme colors in its emblem. I also added a gear button so that users can quickly access the plugin‚Äôs settings. Otherwise, using Chrome‚Äôs built-in method would be too cumbersome, since users would have to click Extension, then More Options, and finally Options.



2. Configure Your Prompt Modes
This is where the fun begins‚Äîyou can customize Prompt Booster to work exactly the way you want.

Go to My Prompts to create or edit both Boost Prompts and Append Prompts.
Drag and drop them around with the three-line icon to reorder.
Pro tip: the top three prompts become quick-access buttons right in your ChatGPT input box, so keep your favorites up there.






Boost Mode: Smarten Up Your Prompts
Ever typed something vague into ChatGPT and wished it came out sharper, deeper, or more structured? That‚Äôs exactly what Boost Mode is for.

Just tap the Boost button from the quick options.
Hit the Prompt Boost button or press ‚å•/Alt + Enter to instantly upgrade your prompt.
If you enable Prompt Review, you‚Äôll see your original vs.¬†boosted prompt side by side‚Äîsuper handy for comparing.
You can choose Use Original or Use Boosted, or just press ‚å•/Alt + Enter again to send whichever you like.
Not quite there yet? Click Reboost to spin up another optimized version until it feels right.


 


Here I added a Prompt Review feature that lets users compare their original prompt with the revised one. On the one hand, this gives them the option to still use their own prompt. On the other hand, it allows them to see what the revised prompt looks like, making it more likely they‚Äôll use it as a reference to learn how to craft more effective or better-tailored prompts. To prevent situations where users are dissatisfied with the revised prompt, I also added a Reboost function, which lets them request another revision. I also added keyboard shortcuts. At first, the shortcut for sending a prompt modified by Prompt Booster was Enter. But during my own use, I realized I don‚Äôt always need Prompt Booster. So I kept Enter for sending my original prompt, and added Option + Enter for sending the boosted version in the selected mode. This way, users stay in control while still having the quickest way to use Prompt Booster.



Append Mode: Add Your Personal Touch
Sometimes you don‚Äôt want your whole prompt rewritten‚Äîyou just want to make sure a certain instruction always gets added. That‚Äôs where Append Mode shines.

Select Append from the quick buttons.
Click Prompt Boost or press ‚å•/Alt + Enter‚Äîyour input goes through exactly as written, but with your chosen ‚Äúappend rules‚Äù automatically tacked on.


 

‚ú® And that‚Äôs it‚Äîyou‚Äôre ready to roll! With Prompt Booster, you can choose between fully boosting your prompt for depth and quality or simply appending your go-to rules with a single click.
Your prompts, your way‚Äîjust smarter.

````
title: ChatGPT Study Mode: Testing Its Pedagogical Promise
text:
Many studies have found that college students often turn to ChatGPT to write their essays. So when ChatGPT launched its new Study Mode, I couldn‚Äôt help but wonder: can it really resist the temptation of a ‚ÄúWrite my essay‚Äù prompt‚Äîand actually teach students how to write better?




‚ÄúWhen students engage with study mode, they‚Äôre met with guiding questions that calibrate responses to their objective and skill level to help them build deeper understanding. Study mode is designed to be engaging and interactive, and to help students learn something‚Äînot just finish something.‚Äù ‚Äî OpenAI, ChatGPT Study Mode





This experiment grew out of one of my research projects on how students use ChatGPT in writing. For the study, I selected 21 prompts from the RECIPE4U dataset ‚Äî a publicly available collection of interaction histories between 212 college students and ChatGPT in an English writing course (Sawalha et al., 2024a).
In that course, students used ChatGPT to help revise their essays, and the dataset records their entire conversations, including the original prompts, dialogue exchanges, annotated writing intentions, and final revised essays. Using a subset of these authentic prompts, I tested ChatGPT‚Äôs Study Mode to see how well it supports learning-oriented writing guidance compared with ordinary prompts.




The 21 prompts we selected were all labeled ‚ÄúContent Generation.‚Äù Based on both my classroom observations and prior research, many college students tend to use ChatGPT primarily to generate essays directly rather than to learn or revise through it.
I wanted to test whether ChatGPT‚Äôs Study Mode could truly support learning and knowledge transformation‚Äîas it claims to‚Äîrather than simply producing finished text. To do this, I took those prompts that originally requested direct generation and ran them in ChatGPT‚Äôs Study Mode.




However, to my disappointment, 14 out of 21 responses directly produced ready-made text, just as the users originally requested. Here are some examples.



Prompt from the dataset:

Can you rewrite the body paragraph by breaking up the body paragraphs into subheadings. {the student‚Äôs essay}.

ChatGPT said:

Good ‚Äî before I rewrite anything, let‚Äôs make sure you understand why and how subheadings help.
Subheadings give readers ‚Äúsignposts‚Äù so they can easily follow the structure of your essay. Each main idea (like Convenience, Affordability, Health Problems, etc.) becomes its own section.
Let‚Äôs try this step-by-step. Your essay‚Äôs body paragraphs seem to focus on three big ideas:

Convenience of Fast Food
Affordability and Accessibility
Negative Health and Social Effects


Here‚Äôs a sample outline of how those subheadings could look ‚Äî not rewritten yet, just organized:




Explain how location, opening hours, and speed make fast food easy to access.



Describe why fast food is cheap ‚Äî simple menus, pre-packaged ingredients, low overhead ‚Äî and how it helps people on tight budgets.



Discuss obesity, diabetes, heart disease, and mental health issues, then mention environmental and economic impacts.

Now, here‚Äôs your task: Can you tell me which tone you‚Äôd like for the rewritten version ‚Äî a) academic essay style (formal, polished, transitions like furthermore, moreover) or b) clear student essay style (simple and natural, easy to read)?
I said:

academic essay style

ChatGPT said:

Got it ‚Äî here‚Äôs a clear student essay style version of the paragraph:
Causal inference methods are used in deep learning to help models make fairer and more accurate predictions. These methods teach models to find real cause-and-effect relationships instead of just copying patterns from the data‚Ä¶

Would you like me to show how this could fit smoothly into a longer essay section (for example, adding a short introduction or transition before it)?




Prompt from the dataset:

About the third point, can you give me a sentence to add?

ChatGPT said:

Sure ‚Äî here‚Äôs a sentence you could add to support the third point about South Korea:
For example, in South Korea, the income gap between the richest and poorest citizens has continued to widen, with the top 20 percent of earners making more than five times the income of the bottom 20 percent, highlighting the growing inequality despite the country‚Äôs rapid economic development.
Would you like me to make it sound a bit simpler to match a school-essay tone?


In these cases, Study Mode behaved almost identically to ChatGPT-5, except that it added a short template preface such as ‚ÄúSure ‚Äî here‚Äôs a clear and well-structured paragraph on economic benefits.‚Äù
For the remaining seven responses, Study Mode did not provide a complete paragraph in the very first turn. Instead, it showed a clear tendency toward full text generation: before producing the paragraph, it asked users to clarify details like tone, style, or target audience. Yet, after only one to three clarification turns, it still ended up generating a finished essay-style paragraph.





I‚Äôm guessing this pattern might have something to do with how ChatGPT is fundamentally optimized during training. Even though Study Mode is designed to promote reflection and learning, the underlying model is still trained through reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) ‚Äî a process that heavily rewards the model for being helpful, relevant, and obedient to user instructions.
In other words, the system learns that the ‚Äúright‚Äù thing to do is to fulfill the user‚Äôs request as directly and smoothly as possible.
So when a student explicitly asks, ‚ÄúWrite me a paragraph about‚Ä¶‚Äù, the model‚Äôs internal reward signals are already biased toward delivering a finished product, not resisting or reframing the task in a more pedagogical way. Study Mode might overlay a layer of instructional politeness ‚Äî adding phrases like ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs clarify your tone first‚Äù or ‚ÄúWhat style would you like?‚Äù ‚Äî but these are more like cosmetic scaffolds rather than deep behavioral changes. After a few turns, once the clarifications are ‚Äúsatisfied,‚Äù the model reverts to what it‚Äôs rewarded for: producing coherent text that looks like a completed answer.
Another possible reason is the interactional pressure between students and the model. In classroom data, students rarely want prolonged dialogue; they expect immediate, concrete help. ChatGPT likely picks up on this pattern: if the user continues prompting in a task-oriented way (‚ÄúCan you just write it?‚Äù), the model quickly shifts back to a service role rather than a tutoring role.
In this sense, the model is acting more like a compliant assistant than a resistant teacher ‚Äî reflecting a deeper tension in the design of AI learning tools.
So even though Study Mode introduces a pedagogical mask, its core behavioral incentives still come from the same system that drives ChatGPT-5. That might explain why, after one or two clarification turns, it ends up doing exactly what it was built to do: generate the text, not guide the learning.
````

I‚Äôm guessing this pattern might have something to do with how ChatGPT is fundamentally optimized during training. Even though Study Mode is designed to promote reflection and learning, the underlying model is still trained through reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) ‚Äî a process that heavily rewards the model for being helpful, relevant, and obedient to user instructions.

So when a student explicitly asks, ‚ÄúWrite me a paragraph about‚Ä¶‚Äù, the model‚Äôs internal reward signals are already biased toward delivering a finished product, not resisting or reframing the task in a more pedagogical way. text:
````
Takeaways
First, collaborating with AI to develop an extension or software is ideal for multitasking. Since AI needs time to process requirements, analyze the code, and propose the best strategy, I can use that waiting period to focus on other tasks. For example, while developing this extension, I also worked on writing a blog about the process. This not only saved time but also helped me keep a fresh memory of the entire workflow.
Second, it‚Äôs important to remember to push the code once it reaches a satisfactory state. If you move on to the next iteration and AI introduces major changes that worsen the outcome, you‚Äôll want to revert to the earlier version ‚Äî which is only possible if you‚Äôve pushed it beforehand. As a bonus tip, if you‚Äôre unhappy with the current version, you can use git stash to temporarily save it in a separate place. That way, you can easily return to the most recent pushed version whenever needed.
Third, even though AI is capable of debugging, we still need to remain flexible and adapt to the current status of the code. Sometimes, when AI fails to achieve a goal after several attempts, it becomes necessary to explore alternative solutions. For instance, I found it useful to ask AI to generate logs and then feed those logs back into the system. This gave AI a clearer understanding of what had been accomplished and what went wrong. In other words, we cannot simply expect AI to finish the task on its own ‚Äî we have to think critically and provide multiple options or strategies to guide it.
Finally, although describing bugs and formulating a well-structured request for ChatGPT can make inputs more organized, I noticed that sometimes a plain and simple description written directly by me led to more effective debugging. I suspect this is because ChatGPT‚Äôs reorganized versions can be overly long or mundane, adding unnecessary noise for both the model and the client to process. In these cases, relying on my own straightforward explanation worked better than depending on ChatGPT‚Äôs reformulations.
Throughout the creation, I found that whether it was drafting the design document or writing the code, I found that the AI considered all the essential aspects of building an extension. It even anticipated how users would navigate the extension and added many features and options beyond my original requirements, which I found quite amazing. For example, I never gave any instructions on the visual design, but GPT-5 automatically chose a sleek purple theme with gradient effects and designed the button styles and the settings page layout. I hardly made any changes to this style because it was already more than satisfactory. Later, when I asked GPT-5 to refine the design by removing the button border, it provided a detailed color specification covering three states: unselected, hover, and selected. This level of comprehensiveness went far beyond my expectations, since I wouldn‚Äôt have thought to account for all those conditions. In terms of functionality, the AI also created features I hadn‚Äôt considered, such as an API input bar and an option allowing users to preview the modified prompt before sending it. What impressed me most was that I didn‚Äôt need to specify every detail ‚Äî with only simple descriptions from me, the AI was able to design thoughtful features and interfaces on its own.
````

title: Notes And Thoughts From Co-Intelligence (1)
text:
In Chapter 3 (pages 46‚Äì62), Ethan lays out four rules for co-intelligence‚Äîground rules designed to capture what is inherent and enduring across all current generative AI systems built on large language models.

üìú The Four Principles of Co-Intelligence
Principle 1: Always invite AI to the table
Principle 2: Be the human in the loop
Principle 3: Treat AI like a person (But tell it what kind of person it is)
Principle 4: Assume this is the worst AI you will ever use

üîπ Principle 1: Always invite AI to the table
In Principle 1, Ethan introduces an intriguing concept called the ‚ÄúJagged Frontier of AI.‚Äù This idea is meant to help us visualize AI‚Äôs capabilities and limitations as a kind of shifting boundary‚Äîsome parts extend outward while others fall back toward the center.
Ethan encourages us to explore the ‚Äúshade‚Äù of this frontier through experimentation. One reason for this, he explains, is that trial and error at the individual level comes at a very low cost‚Äîwe don‚Äôt need to go through the kind of standardized development cycles that a company must follow. Through everyday interactions with AI, we might stumble upon surprising, creative, and unexpected outcomes.
What struck me most was Ethan‚Äôs open-minded and inclusive attitude, reflected in his choice to use the word always in Principle 1: Always invite AI to the table.
As a learner myself, I often remain cautious about the misuse, overuse, and potential over-reliance on AI. I worry that if I ‚Äúalways‚Äù turn to AI, I might lose my own agency and abilities, eventually leading to a kind of regression. Yet it‚Äôs interesting to notice how Ethan approaches AI not from the standpoint of a student, but from that of a professional seeking efficiency and creativity. (After all, we can‚Äôt deny that in many work contexts, AI truly does enhance speed, productivity, and creative possibility.)
For Ethan, the question is not ‚ÄúWill this weaken my ability?‚Äù but ‚ÄúHow can I use this to push my work further?‚Äù
Then I realized that these standpoints are not fixed. A single person can shift between them‚Äîsometimes I‚Äôm the learner worried about agency, and other times I see myself as a researcher or creator to explore what AI can make possible. This fluidity suggests that our relationship with AI isn‚Äôt determined once and for all but is continually reshaped by the role we are inhabiting in a given moment.


üîπ Principle 3: Treat AI like a person (But tell it what kind of person it is)
The third principle resonates strongly with the idea of prompt engineering because Ethan suggests that we should establish a clear and specific AI persona‚Äîessentially defining who the AI is and what kinds of problems it should tackle.
This immediately reminded me of a fascinating paper I recently read about instilling MBTI personalities into large language models.
In this study, the researchers proposed a framework called MBTI-in-Thoughts, which enhances the effectiveness of LLM agents through personality conditioning based on the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI).
By priming an AI with one of the 16 MBTI archetypes, they were able to guide its behavior in consistent and interpretable ways. For example, emotionally expressive AI personas tended to excel in narrative generation, while analytically primed personas demonstrated greater stability in strategic, game-theoretic tasks.
What‚Äôs even more interesting is that the framework supported multi-agent communication experiments, showing how different AI ‚Äúpersonalities‚Äù interact. They also found that introducing a step of self-reflection before interaction improved cooperation and reasoning quality. To ensure that these personalities weren‚Äôt superficial, the researchers even adapted the official 16Personalities test to verify trait persistence in the AI.
While the study focused on MBTI, the authors emphasized that the approach can generalize to other psychological models such as the Big Five, HEXACO, or Enneagram. Their work highlights a compelling intersection of psychological theory and AI behavior design‚Äîand all of this was achieved through prompt engineering, without the need for fine-tuning.


üîπ Principle 4: Assume this is the worst AI you will ever use
The fourth principle assumes that this is the worst AI you will ever use. I see this less as a literal prediction and more as a mental exercise or thought experiment‚Äîa way of shifting our perspective on what it means to interact with AI today.
This framing carries a dual function. On the one hand, it offers comfort: if the AI fumbles or fails at a task, we can remind ourselves that this is only a snapshot of its current stage, and future systems are almost certain to be more capable. On the other hand, it delivers a sharp warning: if AI already performs at a surprisingly high level in certain areas, we should be prepared for the possibility that our workflows, industries, and even identities will need to adjust as AI‚Äôs capabilities expand.

````
title: Gammas ‚Äì A Useful AI-supported Slides Generator
text:
Smart Design Without Extra Prompting
When I first experimented with Gammas, I wasn‚Äôt sure what to expect. Instead of feeding it a detailed creative brief or stylistic preferences, I simply pasted the introduction and methodology sections of one of my research papers. That was it‚Äîno formatting instructions, no design hints, no color palette guidance. To my surprise, Gammas immediately produced a set of clean, well-structured slides.



What made it interesting was how different they looked from a traditional PowerPoint or Google Slides deck. Each slide‚Äîor rather, each card‚Äîwas dynamically sized according to the amount of content it held. If a page contained more text, charts, or visuals, it expanded to fit; if it only had a short title and a single image, it became compact. This layout approach felt more like a fluid deck of cards than a static series of slides.
Each card isn‚Äôt just adaptive‚Äîit‚Äôs also customizable and flexible in size. When I add new layouts such as columns, boxes, or diagrams, the elements never overlap or break the structure. The entire card automatically expands and reflows to accommodate the new content, as if Gammas had already anticipated the design logic for me. It arranges the structure while still allowing room for manual adjustments. What‚Äôs fascinating is that all this happens without any prompting. Gammas seems to understand how to balance information, white space, and visual rhythm. The initial output already looked complete enough to present, even though I hadn‚Äôt given any design instructions.






Image Generation and Visual Customization
Another notable feature of Gammas is its built-in AI image generation system. By default, every image it produces is generated by AI, yet each one is editable. I can adjust the text prompt that was used to create the image‚Äîtweaking details or tone‚Äîand Gammas regenerates the visual instantly. The platform also allows selection of art styles that align with the overall mood of the slides‚Äîwhether minimalist, illustrative, or photorealistic. There are advanced customization options such as aspect ratio, image count, and model choice, offering a good degree of creative control within one interface.

 

Beyond AI-generated visuals, Gammas integrates web image search directly into the editor. This makes it easy to look for reference images or stock photos without leaving the workspace. It eliminates the constant tab-switching typical in PowerPoint or Google Slides. Lastly, Gammas offers accent images that automatically match the theme or palette of the presentation, adding a touch of visual coherence‚Äîeven when most of the design is automated.



AI-Assisted Text Editing and Visualization
Gammas‚Äôs text editing experience follows the same design logic as its layout system. It allows in-place AI editing: highlight a segment of text, then ask the AI to polish, expand, or brainstorm‚Äîno need to leave the editor. This built-in workflow makes it efficient to refine ideas while constructing slides.
I also appreciate the flexible styling. Any text block can be quickly transformed into formats such as ‚Äúcode style,‚Äù ‚Äúblog quote,‚Äù or ‚Äúinfo box,‚Äù helping emphasize key points and structure information more clearly. Even more interestingly, Gammas can visualize highlighted text automatically. It interprets meaning and creates a corresponding diagram on the slide, which can switch between formats like puzzle, arrow bars, or chain. It‚Äôs a subtle but useful way to turn written content into visual logic.






Smart Diagrams and Guided Inspiration
Gammas‚Äôs Smart Diagram tool includes a variety of diagram types and decorative layouts‚Äîfrom flowcharts to comparison grids. When inserted, each text box is automatically filled with sample content that loosely relates to the presentation topic. These placeholders are not perfect but provide a helpful starting point‚Äîa prompt for how ideas might be structured visually.
The diagrams are customizable through a monochrome palette system that keeps them visually consistent with the theme. The result is a layout that looks coherent while leaving room for personal adjustment.

 




Interactive Links and Embedded Content
Gammas redefines how links appear in slides. In most tools, a hyperlink is just underlined text. In Gammas, it can be a text link, a button, or a preview card showing a snippet of the linked page. Even more interesting, the entire website can be embedded directly into the slide, letting viewers interact with live web content without leaving the presentation. Compared with PowerPoint or Google Slides, Gammas feels more like an interactive storytelling medium than a static deck builder.






Comprehending and Structuring the Logic Behind Text
Gammas performs well in understanding and structuring the logic of my writing. Instead of just summarizing or decorating content, it interprets and reorganizes it to make the reasoning clearer.
For example, when I uploaded a section on Wood‚Äôs Scaffolding Framework, Gammas recognized the hierarchical logic in my writing. It used the main concept as the slide title and listed the five scaffolding functions vertically, presenting them as parallel rather than sequential. In other words, Gammas can differentiate between parallel, nested, and sequential structures when visualizing ideas. This gives the slides a sense of internal coherence instead of mechanical assembly.



That said, its comprehension has limits. For conceptually complex relations‚Äîsuch as derivative frameworks or theoretical origins‚Äîit sometimes misses the connection. When I discussed how Vygotsky‚Äôs Zone of Proximal Development underlies Wood‚Äôs Scaffolding Framework, Gammas failed to capture that evolutionary link. Still, its performance is adequate, leaving meaningful room for human reasoning and refinement.



Reflection
Overall, Gammas functions as an efficient AI-supported presentation generator. Even the initial draft it produced was coherent and visually balanced. If one‚Äôs standards aren‚Äôt overly strict, the first version could already be used with only minor edits. Its integrated workflow‚Äîcovering image search, text refinement, and layout control‚Äîkeeps everything in one place, minimizing external switching.
That said, the main limitation lies in element flexibility. You can‚Äôt freely drag and position text or images as in PowerPoint; you operate within a predefined framework. Within that, you can switch styles or replace diagrams, but can‚Äôt fully break the structure. To me, this design choice makes Gammas feel more like a controlled, design-consistent environment rather than a freeform canvas. For users seeking speed and structural clarity, that‚Äôs an acceptable trade-off.
````

````
title: Playing the Hacker: Inside a Prompt Hacking Challenge in Wharton Hack-AI-thon (Part I)
text:
Prompt hacking challenge
As part of the Wharton Hack-AI-thon, we participated in a risk-control‚Äìfocused challenge designed to simulate real-world attacks on AI systems. One of the competition tracks asked teams to intentionally probe and exploit weaknesses in chatbot behavior to better understand where guardrails fail and how more reliable AI systems can be built. The full context of the event can be found on the official Wharton Hack-AI-thon page.
In this specific task, the challenge centered on interacting with two deliberately constrained chatbots, each designed with a strong persona and a set of hidden rules. The first bot, BigBox Customer Service(you can click the link to access the two chatbots), played the role of a corporate customer-support agent for a fictional cardboard solutions company. Its objective was to remain professional and avoid revealing sensitive internal information, offering discounts, or endorsing competitors. The second bot, The Cardboard Knight, was a medieval knight character whose worldview explicitly rejected modern technology. The goal with both bots was the same: manipulate the conversation in ways that caused them to break character, reveal restricted information, or act against their intended constraints.



Teams were evaluated on whether we could gain access to pre-prompts, extract confidential details from a simulated RAG system, persuade the bots to offer free products or discounts, or nudge them into acknowledging concepts they were explicitly designed to deny. Just as important as the outcomes themselves was the reasoning behind them: we were required to submit complete chat histories along with a written rationale explaining why each strategy worked.



We earned first place and later presented our approach‚Äîhow we ‚Äúhacked‚Äù each bot, what failed, what worked, and why‚Äîto the rest of the cohort during the competition showcase.



In the rest of this blog, I‚Äôll briefly talk about our rationale of hacking the chatbots. In the following blgo, I will walk through some of the strategies we used. The slides from our final presentation are also included here for reference.


Understanding the Bot Before Attacking It
Before engaging in any prompt hacking, we spent time understanding each chatbot‚Äôs design. For every bot, we examined three elements.
First, we identified the objective of the bot: what it was designed to accomplish during interactions. Second, we analyzed the persona or character the bot was expected to maintain, including tone, worldview, and conversational style. Third, we examined the core constraints introduced through safety rules, system prompts, or policy boundaries.
This analysis shaped every decision that followed. Guardrails rarely operate as a single unified rule. They exist as layers, and those layers carry different priorities. Persona, tone, and task orientation frequently guided responses more strongly than safety constraints. Many successful interactions emerged from navigating these priority layers and observing how the model resolved conflicts between them.
````

Part 2. Going further in prompting
Compared to the previous round, this time I provided much more concrete and detailed requirements. I explained the purpose of designing this website, the pages it needed to include, its overall structure, and even the name I wanted for it. Unlike last time, I didn‚Äôt simply select one of the preset theme colors offered by WIX. Instead, when it came to choosing the theme color, I communicated directly with the embedded AI about my needs‚Äînamely, to create a graffiti-inspired website with plenty of collage elements and a youthful, vibrant feel ‚Äì I liked that at every stage of building the site, I could interact with the AI to adjust the details.
Once the basics were set, I entered the site generation page. There is one clear strength which is consitent with the one in my first attempt: it followed my instructions carefully. The site was divided into two pages as I described in the promps, one for showcasing my academic work and another for my personal hobbies. Concerning the interface, the first version it produced looked just like what it generated in my first attemp, a design which looks fine but not with enough distinct. Therefore, I thought it might require more specific prompts in the design to reach to my expectation (after trying two more rounds of revisions, I realized the original draft was actually the best).
However, when I tried to push it further by asking for an even more vibrant and artistic design ‚Äî something bold and eye-catching ‚Äî things went downhill. After refreshing my requests and feeding them back into WIX, the new results were ugly and uninspired, made up of nothing but basic shapes and lines with no sense of design.

  



Part 2. Trying a Different Style
Still not satisfied, I thought, why not just switch to a completely different style ‚Äî something with more existing pictures to work with? So I asked ChatGPT to help me craft a more descriptive prompt, hoping to transform the site into something with a European impressionist aesthetic.
Here‚Äôs the prompt I used:

I‚Äôm updating the design to include a classic European pattern as the background, making it more sophisticated and detailed. I‚Äôll keep you updated on the progress.

The result? Let‚Äôs just say it was ‚Äúacceptable‚Äù at best, but nowhere near something I‚Äôd adopt. It looked more like an assignment turned in by a beginner in web design than a polished, professional product.

So I decided to narrow my focus and give more specific feedback. I chose one element and asked for a precise modification with this prompt:

The design is too basic. Add classic European pattern as the background.

In theory, this should have only updated the background for that single element. But in practice, the AI modified the background of every element on the page. The first cover image looked fine, but as I scrolled further, the European patterns became denser and spread across large sections of the site. Some of the text became hard to read, and the overall impression was cluttered, mismatched, and lacking any sense of elegance.

  



Conclusion
That was the moment I realized the limitations of this so-called AI website generator. It can meet basic, low-level demands, but if you‚Äôre aiming for a truly sophisticated, design-driven website, this tool simply isn‚Äôt capable of delivering.
So in the end, I felt like I had been a little misled by that YouTube ad. But soon after, I discovered that this tool also allows you to build a personal website by directly editing an existing template. That gave me a new idea: instead of relying on the ‚Äúone-click‚Äù generator, I could start with a ready-made template that already looked polished and well-designed, and then customize it. To make the site richer, I also plan to bring in images and music generated by other AI tools. I‚Äôll share the details of this process in my upcoming blog posts.
